awd_titl_txt: Theory of Light Hydrogenlike Bound States: Multiloop Corrections in Muonic and Electronic Atoms and Ions
awd_abstract_narration:
An area of fundamental research is the study of the energy levels of hydrogen-like atoms and exotic atoms (atoms where one particle such as an electron is replaced by another such as a muon). Experiments have become more and more accurate, testing the theory at a stronger and stronger level. This supplies a test of our understanding of the physics of these systems. This project will calculate energy levels for systems where there have been discrepancies between theory and experiment. The theoretical results obtained in this research will find applications in the analysis of the forthcoming experimental results on muonic and electronic atoms and ions. This analysis will result in more precise values of the fundamental physical constants, especially the proton radius, as well as radii of the deuteron and alpha particles. These values will find applications in metrology and nuclear physics. New theoretical expressions will be used in the new CODATA analysis of the fundamental physical constants.  In its turn CODATA compilations of the fundamental constants are used in every science classroom, and in numerous fields of science and engineering, from fundamental research to consumer electronics. Graduate and undergraduate students participating in this research will acquire research, computer, problem solving, and presentation skills. Research activity of a graduate student is expected to lead to a PhD thesis. This project will promote international collaboration, as collaboration with foreign scientists is planned. The results of the proposed research will be published in refereed journals, will be presented at domestic and international conferences and workshops, and will be used in teaching graduate courses.

High precision quantum electrodynamics of hydrogenlike bound states is an active field of theoretical research, motivated both by spectacular experimental progress and the intellectual challenge. Despite significant progress in the theory of light, hydrogenlike bound states, there are a number of challenging problems in this field that are addressed in this project. Search for a theoretical explanation of the discrepancy between the value of the proton charge radius obtained from the experiment with muonic hydrogen and the proton charge radius derived from hydrogen spectroscopy and electron-proton scattering is one of the main objectives. Irrespective of the way the proton charge radius controversy will be resolved, an extensive program of research on energy splittings in light muonic atoms and ions (muonic hydrogen, muonic deuterium, and muonic helium ions) is in order to match current and forthcoming experimental results. Methods of nonrelativistic and relativistic quantum electrodynamics will be applied to loosely bound two-particle systems in the proposed research. Theoretical results of the proposed research together with the theoretical results of other authors and with the results of the past and ongoing experiments would allow the determination of more precise values for many fundamental physical constants: the proton charge radius, the Rydberg constant, electron-muon and electron-proton mass ratios, etc.

por.por_cntn:
In the work on this project we addressed the problem of bound states in quantum electrodynamics and quantum chromodynamics. On the one hand these problems have some similarities, but on the other hand they are vastly different. Perturbation theory can be used to calculate energy levels of electromagnetically bound hydrogenlike bound states with very high accuracy. Results of these calculations can be compared with the highly precise measurements of the transition frequencies between these energy levels. From this comparison  we can obtain very accurate values of the fundamental physical constants, like the fine structure constant, electron-muon mass ratio, proton charge radius and some others. Strong interactions are described by quantum chromodynamics that does not allow to use perturbation theory to calculate properties of the respective bound states -- hadrons. One has to rely on other methods to figure out properties of these bound states.

We used quantum electrodynamics perturbation theory to calculate hard three-loop corrections to energy levels of muonium and positronium. Calculation of hard three-loop single-logarithmic and nonlogarithmic contributions to hyperfine splitting in muonium reduced the theoretical error of hyperfine splitting in muonium. It will facilitate comparison between theory and experiment. Together with the theoretical results by other authors and the planned experimental work it will lead to improved determination of the electron-muon mass ratio. Calculation of the hard three-loop corrections to hyperfine splitting in positronium is a next step in development of the theory of hyperfine splitting and improvement of the theoretical methods used in this theory. The obtained results will be important for comparison between theory and experiment in the planned experiments on measurement of this splitting in positronium.

Pentaquarks with hidden charm were experimentally discovered by the LHCb collaboration in 2015. This discovery opened a new chapter in research on the properties of exotic baryons. The most actual goal is interpretation of these exotic resonances, theoretical description of their properties and prediction of possible new baryons with hidden charm. Theoretical obstacles on the route to this goal are numerous, first of all because one cannot use quantum chromodynamics perturbation theory to describe these bound states. Many  theorists started to work on the solution of the hidden pentaquark problem immediately after their discovery. We suggested an interpretation of pentaquarks as hadrocharmonium states. The basic idea is that the hidden charm pentaquarks are bound charmonium-nucleon states. Binding is due to the charmonium chromoelectric polarizability. This mechanism naturally explains narrow width of the pentaquark states. We predicted that the Pc(4450) pentaquark is a member of one of the two almost degenerate hidden-charm baryon octets with spin-parities 1/2- and 3/2-. The masses and decay widths of the octet pentaquarks were calculated. The widths are small and comparable with the width of the Pc(4450) pentaquark, and the masses of the octet pentaquarks satisfy the Gell-Mann–Okubo relation.


New theoretical results on muonium and positronium energy levels obtained in the work on this project will find application in interpretation of the results of new experiments on the muonium and positronium energy levels that are currently going or planned in many laboratories around the world (Switzerland, Japan, Britain, etc.). They also will be used in the coming 2018 CODATA adjustment of the fundamental physical constants. This adjustment will be revolutionary because it will be the first one based on the revised international system of units SI in which the Planck constant h, elementary charge e, Boltzmann constant k, and Avogadro constant NA will have exact values in addition to the speed of light in vacuum c. In its turn the CODATA compilations of the fundamental constants are widely used in every science classroom, and in numerous fields of science and engineering, from fundamental research to consumer electronics.

This project promoted international collaboration, some results were obtained in collaboration with foreign scientists. The results of this research were published in refereed journals and were presented at international conferences and workshops. The results on the newly discovered pentaquarks obtained in this research, can be used (and already were used) as good pedagogical examples in teaching graduate Quantum Mechanics and Quantum Field Theory courses.
